page.title: 7.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will use familiar tools like tables and graphs to represent quadratic functions. These tools will help you discover that finding the sum of the partial areas in a rectangle is the same as applying the distributive property to multiply out the terms in each factor.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Rewrite quadratic expressions in different forms by using an area diagram or the distributive property.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.8.1: Area Diagrams
  • 7.8.2: Using the Distributive Property to Write Equivalent Expressions
    • 7.8.2: Self Check
    • 7.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.8.3: Using Diagrams to Find Equivalent Quadratic Expressions
    • 7.8.3: Self Check
    • 7.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.8.4: Writing Equivalent Expressions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.8.5: Practice
  • 7.8.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.8.1: Area Diagrams
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


  1. Explain why the diagram shows that \(6(3+4)=6 \cdot 3+6 \cdot 4\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The entire diagram represents the product \(6(3+4)\). The upper half represents \(6 \cdot 3\) while the lower half represents \(6 \cdot 4\).


  1. Draw a diagram to show that \(5(x + 2) = 5x + 10\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Diagrams will vary, but should show a large rectangle with two sub-rectangles, with one sub-rectangle representing \(5 \cdot x\), and the other representing \(5 \cdot 2\). For example:

page.title: 7.8.2: Using the Distributive Property to Write Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

Applying the distributive property to multiply out the factors of, or expand, \(4(x+2)\) gives us \(4x+8\), so we know the two expressions are equivalent. We can use a rectangle with side lengths \((x+2)\) and 4 to illustrate the multiplication.


  1. Draw a diagram to show that \(n(2n+5)\) and \(2n^2+5n\) are equivalent expressions.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:


  1. For each expression, use the distributive property to write an equivalent expression. If you get stuck, consider drawing a diagram.
    1. \(6(\frac{1}{3} n + 2)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2n+12\)


    1. \(p(4p+9)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(4p^2+9p\)


    1. \(5r(r+ \frac{3}{5})\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(5r^2+3r\)


    1. \((0.5w+7)w\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(0.5w^2+7w\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to multiply both terms by \(4t\), not just 4. The answer is \(4t^2-3t\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When \(4t\) is multiplied by \(\frac{3}{4}\), the result is \(3t\). The answer is \(4t^2-3t\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \(4t\) by \(t\), then multiply \(4t\) by \(-3\). The result is \(4t^2-3t\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiply each term by \(4t\). The answer is \(4t^2-3t\).

page.title: 7.8.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Distributive Property


Distributive Property

If \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) are real numbers, then:

\(a(b+c)=ab+ac\)

Other forms:

\(a(b-c)=ab-ac\)

\((b+c)a=ba+ca\)


Example 1

Simplify \(3(x + 4)\)

Step 1
Distribute the 3 to both the \(x\) and the 4.

Step 2
Multiply the terms.
\(3(x) + 3(4)\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(3x + 12\)

Example 2

Simplify \(m(7 - 2m)\)

Step 1
Distribute the \(m\) to both the 7 and the \(2m\).

Step 2
Multiply the terms. Recall \(m \cdot m=m^2\).
\(m(7) - m(2m)\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(7m-2m^2\)

Example 3

Simplify \(5x(x-\frac{2}{5})\)

Step 1
Distribute the \(5x\) to both the \(x\) and the \(\frac25\).

Step 2
Multiply the terms. Recall \(x \cdot x=x^2\).
\(5x(x)-5x(\frac{2}{5})\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(5x^2-2x\)

Try It: Distributive Property


Simplify \(7y(4y-\frac{3}{7})\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to simplify the expression using the distributive property:

Step 1
Distribute the \(7y\) to both the \(4y\) and the \(\frac{3}{7}\) .

Step 2
Multiply the terms. Recall \(y \cdot y=y^2\).
\(7y(4y)-7y(\frac{3}{7})\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(28y^2-3y\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.8.3: Using Diagrams to Find Equivalent Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Activity


  1. Here is a diagram of a rectangle with side lengths \(x+1\) and \(x+3\). Use this diagram to show that \((x+1)(x+3)\) and \(x^2+4x+3\) are equivalent expressions.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x \cdot x =x^2\)
\(1 \cdot x=x\)
\(x \cdot 3=3x\)
\(1 \cdot 3=3\)

Adding these together gives \(x^2+4x+3\).


  1. Draw diagrams to help you write an equivalent expression for each of the following:
    1. \((x+5)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The diagram should show partial products that add up to \(x^2+10x+25\).


    1. \(2x(x+4)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The diagram should show partial products that add up to \(2x^2+8x\).


    1. \((2x+1)(x+3)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The diagram should show partial products that add up to \(2x^2+7x+3\).


    1. \((x+m)(x+n)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The diagram should show partial products that add up to \(x^2+xn+mx+xn\) or \(x^2+(m+n)x+mn\).


  1. Write an equivalent expression for each expression without drawing a diagram. Use the distributive property to help. Remember FOIL for multiplying binomials: Multiply the First terms, the Outer terms, the Inner terms, and the Last terms.
    1. \((x+2)(x+6)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+8x+12\)


    1. \((x+5)(2x+10)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2x^2+20x+50\)



Video: Using Diagrams to Find Equivalent Quadratic Expressions

Watch the following video to learn more about using diagrams to find equivalent quadratic expressions.




Extending Your Thinking

Image 1

Image 2

  1. Are Image 1 and Image 2 equivalent? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, because \(x \cdot x+5(1x)+6(1)=(x+2)(x+3)\).


  1. What does this tell you about an equivalent expression for \(x^2+5x+6\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This shows that an equivalent expression is \((x+2)(x+3)\).


  1. Is there a different non-zero number of 1-by-1 squares that we could use instead that would allow us to arrange the combined figures into a single large rectangle?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

We could use four 1-by-1 squares. This would give the expression \(x^2+5x+4\). The rectangle would be \((x + 4)(x + 1)\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to distribute the 2 in \((x + 2)\) to the \((x + 4)\). The answer is \(x^2+6x+8\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply the \(x\) times the \((x + 4)\), then multiply the 2 by \((x + 4)\). Combine like terms. You can also draw a diagram.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Like terms are combined with addition, not multiplication. The answer is \(x^2+6x+8\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\) in \((x + 2)\) must also be multiplied by the 4 in \((x + 4)\). The answer is \(x^2+6x+8\).

page.title: 7.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Multiplying Binomials

Write an expression equivalent to \((x + 2)(x + 5)\).

Step 1
Distribute. Use FOIL. Multiply the First terms, Outer terms, Inner terms, and Last terms.

Step 2
Write out the four terms.
\(x^2+5x+2x+10\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(x^2+7x+10\)

Try It: Multiplying Binomials

Write an expression equivalent to \((x + 7)(x + 3)\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to multiply binomial expressions:

Step 1
Distribute.

Step 2
Write out the four terms.
\(x^2+3x+7x+10\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(x^2+10x+21\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.8.4: Writing Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. Draw a diagram to show that \((3x+1)(x+2)\) is equivalent to \(3x^2+7x+2\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Diagram should show partial products of \(3x(x)\), \(6x\), \(x\), and 2, which add up to \(3x^2+7x+2\).


  1. Is \((x+4)^2\) equivalent to \(2x^2+8x+8\)? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. \((x+4)(x+4)=x^2+4x+4x+16=x^2+8x+16\).

page.title: 7.8.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Choose the expression that best describes the diagram.

Correct! \((2x+5)(x+3)\) is equivalent to \(2x^2+11x+15\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((2x+5)(x+3)\) is equivalent to \(2x^2+11x+15\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. In questions a–d, match each expanded quadratic expression with an equivalent expression written as a product.
    1. \(x^2+12x+32\)

Correct! \((x+8)(x+4)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((x+8)(x+4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(x^2+5x+6\)

Correct! \((x+2)(x+3)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((x+2)(x+3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(x^2+6x+8\)

Correct! \((x+4)(x+2)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again?

The correct answer is:\((x+4)(x+2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(x^2+8x+12\)

Correct! \((x+2)(x+6)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is:\((x+2)(x+6)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select three expressions that are equivalent to \(x^2+4x\).

Correct! \(x(x+4)\), \((x+2)^2-4\), \((x+4)x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.8.2-7.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x(x+4)\), \((x+2)^2-4\), \((x+4)x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Tyler drew a diagram to expand \((x+5)(2x+3)\).

    1. Tyler’s diagram is incorrect. Choose the sentence that describes Tyler’s mistake.

Correct! Tyler added 5 and 2 and 5 and 3 instead of multiplying them.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Tyler added 5 and 2 and 5 and 3 instead of multiplying them. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the correct expanded form of \((x+5)(2x+3)\)?

Correct! \(2x^2+13x+15\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is : \(2x^2+13x+15\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.8.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Rewrite quadratic expressions in different forms by using an area diagram or the distributive property.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.8.1: Area Diagrams
    • In this activity, you drew area diagrams to represent multiplication.
  • 7.8.2: Using the Distributive Property to Write Equivalent Expressions
    • In this activity, you used diagrams to write equivalent expressions, and then used the distributive property to find the product of a monomial times a binomial.
    • 7.8.2: Self Check
    • 7.8.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.8.3: Using Diagrams to Find Equivalent Quadratic Expressions
    • In this activity, you continued to use diagrams to find equivalent expressions, and then used the distributive property to multiply binomials by binomials.
    • 7.8.3: Self Check
    • 7.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.8.4: Writing Equivalent Expressions
    • In this activity, you multiplied binomial expressions that had coefficients in front of \(x\).

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.8.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
